occurrences.line_text: Gathering againe, her Host she did renew,
Which th'Infants tutors gathering to feare,
But gathering him round about more neare,
Gathering sweet daffadillyes, to haue made
Whilest he to gathering of the gold did fall.
And gathering them vnto her citties gate,
Gathred themselues about her body round,
Gathred the Troian reliques sau'd from flame,
With gaudie girlonds, or fresh flowrets dight
That greatest Gloriana to him gaue,
And to the Dwarfe a while his needlesse spere he gaue.
The one of them he gaue a message too,
The which her lauish louers to her gaue;
For that I would not yeeld, that to Sans-foy I gaue.
He gaue her gold and purple pall to weare,
Forthwith he gaue in charge vnto his Squire,
Gaue goodly gifts, the signes of gratefull mynd,
Prince Arthur gaue a boxe of Diamond sure,
Which to requite, the Redcrosse knight him gaue
And gaue it him in hand: his hand did quake,
Almightie God her gaue such powre, and puissance great.
But wise Speranza gaue him comfort sweet,
To whom the carefull charge of him she gaue,
Whose face he made, all beasts to feare, and gaue
He did supply their want, and gaue them euer free.
Whereof Georgos he thee gaue to name;
He thence departing gaue for his paines hyre.
Life and long health that gratious ointment gaue,
And sacred pledges he both gaue, and had,
And after gaue a grone so deepe and low,
Vptaking, to the Palmer gaue to beare;
Gaue him great ayd, and made him more inclind:
Of deadly drugs I gaue him drinke anon,
Feare gaue her wings, and rage enforst my flight;
Had kindled: that she gaue into his hond,
Gaue wondrous great contentment to the knight,
Ne gaue him leaue to bid that aged sire
And to that Damzell thankes gaue for reward.
Of hellish Styx, which hidden vertue to it gaue.
Gaue signes of grudge and discontentment vaine:
Gaue him great hart, and hope of victory.
They gaue fresh charge, their forces gan to faile,
Therein gaue light, and flam'd continually:
He also gaue to fugitiues of Spayne,
And to him gaue for wife his daughter bright,
He gaue in wedlocke to Maximian,
How much to her we owe, that all vs gaue,
That gaue vnto vs all, what euer good we haue.
But ground he gaue, and lightly leapt areare:
And gaue against his mother earth a gronefull sownd.
That blushing to her laughter gaue more grace,
And scarse them leasure gaue, her passing to behold.
With which faire Britomart gaue light vnto the day.
And eke the Redcrosse knight gaue her good aid,
And gaue vnto king Ryence for his gard,
For thy she gaue him warning euery day,
Thy life she gaue, thy life she doth deserue:
The rest vpon her person gaue attendance great.
It forth she cald, and gaue it streight in charge,
Thereto feare gaue her wings, and neede her courage taught.
Whom Venus to him gaue for meed of worthinesse.
Gaue them safe conduct, till to end they came:
Assayld the flame, the which eftsoones gaue place,
And gaue him being, commune to them twaine:
And gaue her leaue at pleasure forth to passe.
And so gaue way vnto his fell intent:
Which straight flew ope, and gaue her way to ride.
That girdle gaue the vertue of chast loue,
Long time resist, gaue place to kindly rest,
But for aduantage ground vnto him gaue,
Which Britomart him gaue, when he did her prouoke.
She gaue vnto him, gotten by her slight
The portion of that good, which Fortune gaue her,
And gaue them gifts and things of deare delight.
And in his hand a distaffe to him gaue,
That gaue none other place. Which when as hee
And gaue to them great liuing and large fee:
Gaue vnto her great comfort and reliefe,
Vnto his horses gaue his guests for meat,
Gaue way vnto his horses speedie flying,
Both vnassaylable, gaue him great ayde:
Which gaue beginning to her woe and wretchednesse.
All to his hands, and gaue him soueraine powre
Who gaue him roiall giftes and riches rare,
Gaue leaue vnto his ghost from thraldome bound,
Ne to their force gaue way, that was great wonder,
Albe that it most safety to him gaue,
Who when he gaue me armes, in field to fight,
Gaue me a shield, in which he did endosse
The morrow next, ne gaue him longer day;
She freely gaue that Castle for his paine,
But gaue them streight vnto that Squire againe,
Gaue euidence, that they were all betrayd,
And gaue his foe good hope of victory.
That way to them he gaue forth right to pas.
Then when she wakt, they all gaue one consent,
They prayd him sit, and gaue him for to feed
Gaue it to Coridon, and said he wonne it well.
Which gaue him hope, and did him halfe perswade,
But gently waking them, gaue them the time of day.
Whilest ye in durance dwelt, ye to me gaue
And tell him for his sake thy life thou gauest.
The more it gauld, and grieu'd him night and day,
But threw his gauntlet as a sacred pledge,
In whose great shield was writ with letters gay
Their gay attire: each others greater pride does spight.
Adorned all with gold, and girlonds gay,
Greatly aduauncing his gay cheualree.
And tassels gay. Wyde wonders ouer all
That her gay garments staynd with filthy gore,
In which were not rich tyres, nor garments gay,
And deckt himselfe with feathers youthly gay,
Gay steed with spurs did pricke, the good Sir Mortdant was.
These two gay knights, vowd to so diuerse loues,
But for in court gay portaunce he perceiu'd,
And at her backe a bow and quiuer gay,
She her gay painted plumes disorderid,
Great glory and gay spoile sure hast thou got,
Amidst a flocke of Damzels fresh and gay,
And that gay paire issuing on the shore
Faire shields, gay steedes, bright armes be my delight:
And thereon sat a woman gorgeous gay,
With his gay Squire issuing did espy,
Gan choose his dame with Basciomani gay,
Gay girlonds, from the Sun their forheads faire to shade.
Of your gay sonne, that giues ye so good ayd
Their goodly meriment, and gay felicitie.
Him shaped thus, she deckt in garments gay,
Her garments gay with scales of fish, that all did fill.
Her golden locks, that were in tramels gay
How euer gay and goodly be the style,
All deckt with crownes, & chaynes, and girlands gay,
That her gay clothes did in discolour die.
How euer gay their blossome or their blade
Dispreds the glorie of her leaues gay;
Yet is that glasse so gay, that it can blynd
Deckt with greene boughes, and flowers gay beseene.
To them, that list, the worlds gay showes I leaue,
That all this worlds gay showes, which we admire,
Yet shortly gaynd, that losse exceeded farre:
Gaynd in Nemea goodly victoree;
Till aged Hely by dew heritage it gaynd.
To gayne so goodly guerdon, as she spake:
Ill by ensample good doth often gayne.
That enterprize, for greatest glories gayne.
So fare on foote till thou another gayne,
Hence fare on foot, till he an horse haue gayned.
No fayrer conquest, then that with goodwill is gayned.
For feare her mistresse shold haue knowledge gayned,
Vnto her Queene, his freedome to haue gayned;
Vntill his owne true loue his freedome gayned,
As she had got thereby, and gayned a great stake.
The which in all mens liking gayned place,
For greater conquest of hard loue he gaynes,
So mak'st thou kings, & gaynest wrongfull gouernement.
The third him ouerthrowes, and gayns
In which he had good right gaynst all, that it gainesayd.
Deuoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd,
And gazd vpon with gaping wonderment.
Gaz'd after him, as fowle escapt by flight;
He gaz'd about, and stared horriblie,
Do ride each other, vpon her to gaze:
To gaze on earthly wight, that with the Night durst ride.
To gaze on them; who forth by them doe pace,
Or liking find to gaze on earthly mould,
Whom thus at gaze, the Palmer gan to bord
And with fell looke and hollow deadly gaze
And round about themselues a while did gaze,
That men on him the more might gaze alone.
Low looking dales, disloignd from common gaze;
But thought, that she thereon could neuer gaze her fill.
They ceast their clamors vpon them to gaze;
For what hath all that goodly glorious gaze
Awhile on her they greedily did gaze,
So as they gazed after her a while,
So inly smot, that as one, which had gazed
But euermore and more vpon it gazed,
But gazed on their harmes, not pittying their estate.
He gazed still vpon that snowy mayd;
Downe on his golden feete he often gazed,
Nor happie howre, beheld with gazefull eye,
Couered from peoples gazement with a vele.
Like lightening flash, that hath the gazer burned,
Great ruth in all the gazers harts did grow,
And gazers sense with double pleasure fed,
Ne rov'd at randon after gazers guyse,
The kingly beast vpon her gazing stood;
By them they passe, all gazing on them round,
The Gods stand gazing on, when she does ride
Where earely waite him many a gazing eye,
To thinke of wight so faire, but gazing stood,
He would them gazing blind, or turne to other hew.
As he thereon stood gazing, he might see
And gazing wonder they their minds did fill;
Gazing a while at his vnwonted guise;
On which when gazing him the Palmer saw,
And gazing each on other, nought bespake:
Stood gazing, as if suddein great affright
Her greedy eyes with gazing a long space:
And gazing on that Chambers ornament,
Stood gazing, filled were with rufull tine,
All on her gazing wisht, and vowd, and prayd,
And he himselfe long gazing thereupon,
Yet ouer him she there long gazing stood,
Thus gazing long, at them much wondred he,
And thereuppon long while stood gazing still,
Which there stood gazing from the Citties wall
Caught like the bird, which gazing still on others stands.
So stood he still long gazing thereupon,
Wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue do thus expell:
Wrath is a fire, and gealosie a weede,
So shall wrath, gealosie, griefe, loue dye and decay.
But gnawing Gealosie out of their sight
Without fell rancor, or fond gealosie;
For peeuish gealosie:
That all his hart with gealosie did swell;
Griefe, and despight, and gealosie, and scorne
Forgot he was a man, and Gealosie is hight.
Fowle Gealosie, that turnest loue diuine
Ne wicked enuie, ne vile gealosy
Full of great enuie and fell gealosy,
That is the father of fowle gealosy,
Into huge waues of griefe and gealosye
That being free from feare and gealosye,
Which when he saw, he burnt with gealous fire,
Still flying from his thoughts and gealous feare;
And with her gealous termes his open eares abused.
In which we long time without gealous feares,
Then wound of gealous worme, and shame of such repriefe.
And to be free from hard restraint and gealous feares.
Empoisned was with priuy lust, and gealous dred.
Deceiu'd of gealous Iuno, did require
That stryfull hag with gealous discontent
The which like thornes did pricke his gealous hart,
And ghesse the man to be dismayd with gealous dread.
For fell despight, and gnaw his gealous hart,
That all his gealous feare he false had found,
Of their franke loues, free from all gealous spyes:
Whose gealous dread induring not a peare,
And many gealous thoughts conceiu'd in vaine,
And byte his lip, and euen for gealousie
An hideous Geant horrible and hye,
The same before the Geants gate he blew,
Aray thy selfe in her most gorgeous geare,
But when he saw her toy, and gibe, and geare,
Clad in a vesture of vnknowen geare,
Thus goe they both together to their geare,
Ere he were throughly buckled to his geare;
That to Sir Calidore was easie geare;
So huge a burden on such broken geare,
And spoyling all her geares and goodly ray,
Found nothing that he said, vnmeet nor geason,
The Geaunt strooke so maynly mercilesse,
So daunted when the Geaunt saw the knight,
From an huge Geaunt, that with hideous
So ran the Geauntesse vnto the fight;
That Geauntesse Argante is behight,
That Geauntesse, is not such, as she seemed,
Of an huge Geauntesse whylome was bred;
Saue an huge nation of the Geaunts broode,
And Gehons golden waues doe wash continually.
They softly wipt away the gelly blood
Wrath, gelosie, griefe, loue this Squire haue layd thus low.
And whally eyes (the signe of gelosy,)
The gnawing anguish and sharpe gelosy,
But like a ghastly Gelt, whose wits are reaued,
Another Damzell, as a precious gemme,
Adornd with gemmes and owches wondrous faire,
Adorned all with gemmes of endlesse price,
Her selfe, adorn'd with gems and iewels manifold.
And fetch from heauen thy great Genealogie,
Were by them slaine by generall consent;
Of life, and generation of all
Great father he of generation
In generation seeke to quench their inward fire.
So fertile be the flouds in generation,
And generous stout courage did inspire,
Through secret feeling of his generous spright,
They in that place him Genius did call:
Old Genius the porter of them was,
Old Genius, the which a double nature has.
Well worthy impe, said then the Lady gent,
He lou'd, as was his lot, a Ladie gent,
A knight had wrought against a Ladie gent;
Forwasted all, till Genuissa gent
Faire mote he thee, the prowest and most gent,
For they all seemed curteous and gent,
Was vsd of Knights and Ladies seeming gent:
Of courteous knights, the Prince, and Faery gent,
Hauing farre off espyde a Tassell gent,
Therefore, faire Sir, for loue of knighthood gent,
Ne foot could further moue: the Lady gent
Kings Queenes, Lords Ladies, Knights & Damzels gent
In th'hearing of full many Knights and Ladies gent.
Within a wood, whereas a Ladie gent
All ciuill vsage and gentility,
And sing of Knights and Ladies gentle deeds;
In loues and gentle iollities arrayd,
A Gentle Knight was pricking on the plaine,
As gentle Shepheard in sweete euen-tide,
Who oft is wont to trouble gentle Sleepe.
With gentle blandishment and louely looke,
Tho can she weepe, to stirre vp gentle ruth,
Much grieu'd to thinke that gentle Dame so light,
Did search, sore grieued in her gentle brest,
Which to expresse, he bends his gentle wit,
To loue this gentle Lady, whom ye see,
When nigh he drew vnto this gentle payre
A gentle Husher, Vanitie by name
With gentle wordes he can her fairely greet,
A gentle Hynd, the which the louely boy
During which time her gentle wit she plyes,
On gentle Dame, so hurtlesse, and so trew:
The gentle virgin left behind alone
Hereof this gentle knight vnweeting was,
A gentle youth, his dearely loued Squire
Ah Ladie deare, quoth then the gentle knight,
For ruth of gentle knight so fowle forlore:
To be vpbrought in gentle thewes and martiall might.
His tombling billowes rolls with gentle rore:
Till gentle Vna thus to him gan say;
Thine, O then, said the gentle Redcrosse knight,
The gentle knight; who nought to him replide,
When as the gentle Redcrosse knight did vew,
There fairely them receiues a gentle Squire,
And by her side there sate a gentle paire
Vp rose the gentle virgin from her place,
When gentle Vna saw the second fall
For neuer gentle knight, as he of late,
This gentle knight into so great distresse,
Where sate a gentle Lady all alone,
Eftsoone she said, Ah gentle trustie Squire,
A gentle Ladie, or her wrong through might:
Or euer gentle Damzell so abuse:
For well ye worthie bene for worth and gentle thewes.
As gentle Hynd, whose sides with cruell steele
The gentle knight her soone with carefull paine
And all that gentle noriture ensu'th:
To thinke without desert of gentle deed,
Proper to gentle bloud; some others faine
O wretched man, that would abuse so gentle Dame.
A gentle streame, whose murmuring waue did play
That gentle Ladie did to him impart,
But louely peace, and gentle amitie,
Of courteous clemencie in gentle hart.
And with vncomely weedes the gentle waue accloyes.
Gramercy Mammon (said the gentle knight)
So streightly God doth iudge. But gentle knight,
Till him the Prince with gentle court did bord;
Yet was she woo'd of many a gentle knight,
Where gentle court and gracious delight
As if some pensiue thought co[n]straind her gentle spright.
Gentle Madame, why beene ye thus dismaid,
Another Damsell of that gentle crew,
Polluted this same gentle soyle long time:
Till gentle Alma seeing it so late,
Had not his gentle Squire beheld his paine,
O thou faire sonne of gentle Faery,
The gentle warbling wind low answered to all.
Which outrage when those gentle knights did see,
Faire Ladies, and of many a gentle knight,
And in each gentle hart desire of honour breeds.
Or rudely sdeigne a gentle harts request;
And euery knight, and euery gentle Squire
A gentle knight with so vnknightly blame:
It ill beseemes a knight of gentle sort,
Such secret ease felt gentle Britomart,
And friends to termes of gentle truce entize,
But loue, that is in gentle brest begonne,
At last blow vp some gentle gale of ease,
But Timias, the Princes gentle Squire,
Was earst impressed in her gentle spright:
But gentle Sleepe enuyde him any rest;
Serued a gentle Lady of great sway,
The gentle Squire came ryding that same way,
Thereat she blushing said, Ah gentle Squire,
With gentle murmure, that his course they did restraine.
In gentle Ladies brest, and bounteous race
And gentle sprite deforme with rude rusticity.
To sleepe, the whiles a gentle slombring swowne
And eke the gentle shepheard swaynes, which sat
Spare, gentle sister, with reproch my paine to eeke.
With sugred words and gentle blandishment,
And sweet loue gentle fits emongst them throwes,
Her gentle speach applide, that in short space
That gentle Lady, whom I loue and serue,
I might do seruice vnto gentle Dames,
Ah gentle Squire (quoth he) tell at one word,
This gentle Damzell, whom I wrote vpon,
Yet still with gentle countenaunce retained,
In th'open freshnesse of the gentle aire,
He gan make gentle purpose to his Dame,
And there with many gentle termes her faire besought.
Ah gentle knight (said then Sir Satyrane)
But fast good will with gentle curtesyes,
The man by gentle meanes, to let vs in,
And shewd her selfe in all a gentle curteous Dame.
Purpose was moued by that gentle Dame,
The gentle Lady, loose at randon left,
Ah gentle knight, whose deepe conceiued griefe
Hath outrag'd you, and thrald your gentle make.
As gentle Ladies helplesse misery.
And gentle pangues, with which he maked meeke
For she was gentle, and of milde aspect,
Said, Gentle Dame, reward enough I weene
Hath no lesse griefe endured for your gentle sake.
But most faire Amoret, whose gentle spright
Was much empassiond in her gentle sprite,
But that young Knight, which through her gentle deed
Ah gentle knight then false Duessa sayd,
Mongst gentle Knights to nourish euermore?
Ah gentle knights (quoth he) how may that bee,
That twixt themselues did gentle purpose make
All which, when gentle Canacee beheld,
To ioyous feast and other gentle play;
Till that at last the gentle Amoret
The gentle Scudamour, whose hart whileare
When gentle sleepe his heauie eyes would close;
And pyning anguish hid in gentle hart,
Ah gentle Scudamour, vnto your grace
Ye gentle Knights, whom fortune here hath brought,
Continuall siege vnto her gentle hart;
The louely Amoret, whose gentle hart
It was my lot to loue a gentle swaine,
And that same gentle Squire arriu'd in place,
Which drery sight the gentle Squire espying,
She left the gentle Squire with Amoret:
That he whilome some gentle swaine had beene,
The gentle Squire recouers grace,
Which to this gentle Squire did happen late.
Thus long this gentle bird to him did vse,
Her gentle Squire through her displeasure did pertake.
No seruice lothsome to a gentle kind;
These gentle Ladies will misdeeme too light,
This gentle crew gan from their eye-lids chace
So as it fell there was a gentle Squire,
Me seemes the gentle hart should most assured bind.
To yeeld strong succour to that gentle swayne,
Were Britomart, and gentle Scudamour,
With gentle words perswading them to friendly peace.
Aye me to see that gentle maide so tost.
Mote we entreat you, sith this gentle crew
Then hearke ye gentle knights and Ladies free,
Soft rombling brookes, that gentle slomber drew;
But she in gentle wise me entertayned,
Holding her hand vpon her gentle hart;
With many a gentle Muse, and many a learned wit.
The first, the gentle Shure that making way
And with their boughes the gentle plants did beat.
Vpon a day she found this gentle childe,
Much did his words the gentle Ladie quell,
A gentle Faulcon sitting on an hill,
Doth beat vpon the gentle bird in vaine,
This gentle knight himselfe so well behaued,
Ah gentle Knights, what meane ye thus vnwise
Thence forth they passed with that gentle Mayd,
The gentle knights reioyced much to heare
With those two gentle youthes, which him did guide,
Much was the Ladie in her gentle mind
Both noble armes and gentle curtesie.
As then the guize was for each gentle swayne;
At length bespake; What meanes this, gentle swaine?
But then aread, thou gentle chyld, wherefore
Then turning backe vnto that gentle boy,
Faire gentle swayne, and yet as stout as fayre,
In gentle thewes, and such like seemely leres.
Which ye haue gathered to your gentle hart,
The gentle minde by gentle deeds is knowne.
The gentle minde by gentle deeds is knowne.
That gentle bloud will gentle manners breed;
That gentle bloud will gentle manners breed;
The gentle Aladine did earst inuade,
With which his gentle words and goodly wit
Allur'd with myldnesse of the gentle wether,
Chasing the gentle Calepine around,
The gentle bloud, how euer it be wrapt
Yet will it shew some sparkes of gentle mynd,
Yet shewd some token of his gentle blood,
By gentle vsage of that wretched Dame.
So milde humanity, and perfect gentle mynd.
Some goodly person, and of gentle race,
Ne yet that gentle Squire, for grieuous paine
Like as the gentle hart it selfe bewrayes,
In doing gentle deedes with franke delight,
The gentle Prince not farre away they spyde,
Nathelesse for all his speach, the gentle knight
In th'harts of many a knight, and many a gentle squire.
When as the gentle Squire, with faire Serene,
His gentle heart with indignation sweld,
He would him scorne, that to his gentle mynd
Y e gentle Ladies, in whose soueraine powre
Who after thraldome of the gentle Squire,
I was belou'd of many a gentle Knight,
It was his owne true groome, the gentle Squire,
When first the gentle Squire at variaunce fell
Great trauell hath the gentle Calidore
And tooke their gentle offer: so adowne
The gentle knight, as he that did excell
Thus did the gentle knight himselfe abeare
And at the foote thereof, a gentle flud
